snippet.title: Buy, hold, sell: $A impact on Boral, James Hardie, Ansell
snippet.content:
Centennial Asset's Matthew Kidman talks with NAOS Asset's Ben Rundle and Totus Capital's Sam Granger about the impact of the strong Australian dollar on stocks. Boral
Sam Granger: Sell. It's capital intensive and high price to earnings vs the market. We don't like that business. Ben Rundle: It's a hold for me. I think that that acquisition they made of Headwaters gives them good exposure to US infrastructure spend, but it's very expensive. James Hardie
Ben Rundle: Yeah, it's a buy for me. Some of the peers in the US have reported very strongly only very recently and James Hardie is taking market share in that space. Sam Granger: It's a hold for us. They've had operational issues, senior management turnover. That concerns us, it's a hold. Ansell
Sam Granger: We're buying Ansell. There's low negativity about this stock. It's got a great track record, high ROE, it's a buy.
Ben Rundle: Yep, it's a buy for me too. They'll have more visibility on their input costs now post the restructure and there's a buyback to come too, so it's a buy. Buy stocks?
Ben Rundle: Resmed. I think the Aussie dollar will come back down. Resmed is a good business that's come back on its earnings. Result was a short-term hiccup. It is very well run, high barriers to entry, good return on equity, so I think you can buy it on the dip. Sam Granger: Hansen Technologies. We think Hansen is a buy. Their founder owns a material part of the stock, he's a great capital allocator, they're following a model which has worked for Constellation Software in the US, so we think that's a buy.
